user_message:
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.1 is: A project shall not contain unreachable code.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of OS_ObjectIdFindByName:
```c
int32 OS_ObjectIdFindByName(osal_objtype_t idtype, const char *name, osal_id_t *object_id)
{
    int32             return_code;
    OS_object_token_t token;

    /*
     * As this is an internal-only function, calling it with NULL is allowed.
     * This is required by the file/dir/socket API since these DO allow multiple
     * instances of the same name.
     */
    ARGCHECK(name, OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND);
    LENGTHCHECK(name, OS_MAX_API_NAME, OS_ERR_NAME_TOO_LONG);

    return_code = OS_ObjectIdGetByName(OS_LOCK_MODE_GLOBAL, idtype, name, &token);
    if (return_code == OS_SUCCESS)
    {
        *object_id = token.obj_id;

        OS_ObjectIdRelease(&token);
    }

    return return_code;
}
```
</target_code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
ARGCHECK(name, OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 2.1 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: The ARGCHECK(name, OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND) invocation is a macro that performs a runtime check (for example: if (name == NULL) { return OS_ERR_NAME_NOT_FOUND; }). This yields conditional control flow: when name is non-NULL the subsequent code is reachable, and when name is NULL the function returns early. There is no code that can never be executed under any possible program flow, so Rule 2.1 is not violated. (A true violation would require code that is impossible to reach under any circumstances, e.g. code after an unconditional return or after an always-true infinite loop.)
